official-title.#text:
Recognizing the sesquicentennial of West
		  Virginia statehood.

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Oversight and Government
			 Reform

cosponsor.#tail:
) submitted the following
			 resolution; which was referred to the

text.#text:
recognizes the sesquicentennial of West
			 Virginia statehood; and

encourages all West Virginians to observe
			 such day with appropriate ceremonies and activities on this historic
			 occasion.

Whereas 2013 marks 150 years since the United States
			 admitted West Virginia as the 35th State in the Union;

Whereas the territory that is now the State of West
			 Virginia was originally part of the Commonwealth of Virginia;

Whereas, on May 23, 1861, Virginia voters ratified the
			 Secession Ordinance to leave the United States and join the Confederacy;

quote.#text:
the people of Virginia to
			 separate from and wage war against the government of the United States and
			 against citizens of neighboring states[.]

text.#text:
Whereas the Second Wheeling Convention declared all State
			 offices in Virginia vacant, and all acts of the General Assembly to be null and
			 void by virtue of its attempt to force

Whereas, on October 24, 1861, residents of the area that
			 is now West Virginia voted to approve West Virginia statehood;

Whereas West Virginia formally joined the Union on June
			 20, 1863; and

quote.#text:
[T]he admission of the
			 new state, turns that much slave soil to free; and thus, is a certain, and
			 irrevocable encroachment upon the cause of the rebellion. The division of a
			 State is dreaded as a precedent. But a measure made expedient by a war, is no
			 precedent for times of peace. It is said that the admission of West Virginia,
			 is secession, and tolerated only because it is our secession. Well, if we call
			 it by that name, there is still difference enough between secession against the
			 constitution, and secession in favor of the constitution. I believe the
			 admission of West Virginia into the Union is expedient.

text.#text:
Whereas President Lincoln recognized the importance of
			 West Virginia’s admission to the Union by writing

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 HRES 151 IH: Recognizing the sesquicentennial of West Virginia statehood.
